awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Controlling Polymer Degradation, Microstructures, and Sequences via Living Alternating Polymerization of Cyclopropenes and Low-Strain Cyclic Olefins
awd_abstract_narration:
Polymers are ubiquitous and serve as important and versatile materials in a myriad of societal sectors, and their properties are dictated by the polymer structures.  In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Prof. Yan Xia of Stanford University develops new synthetic strategies to collectively address the challenges in controlling polymer structure, functionality and degradability.  Fundamental studies and method development of this project aim to enable the synthesis of highly functionalized and precisely structured polymers with tailored properties. This project provides valuable training experiences for undergraduate and graduate students to continue to advance our ability to synthesize complex macromolecular structures. This program integrates educational endeavors at several levels to 1) use after-school educational activities and social media to facilitate recruitment and retention of high school students, especially underrepresented students in the Bay Area; 2) enhance the public awareness of soft materials, both commodity and high-end plastics, enabled by new chemistry and engineering; 3) interface organic chemistry with materials science in undergraduate and graduate education to cultivate interdisciplinary researchers.

The goal of this research is to provide new insights of metathesis chemistry, new patterns of monomer reactivity, and new synthetic strategies to prepare well-defined polymers and materials with tailored properties. This project develops living alternating ring-opening metathesis polymerization (AROMP) and thermodynamically driven single monomer additions to control polymer backbone and side chain functionalities, microstructures, and monomer sequences. The approach to tune materials properties and assembly behaviors of the resulting polymers is by controlling the structural regularity.It also integrates broader educational endeavors to: 1) facilitate recruitment and retention of underrepresented students in the Bay Area in science majors through local visits and social media; 2) enhance the public awareness of both commodity and high-end plastics enabled by new chemistry; and 3) interface organic chemistry with polymer science in Stanford undergraduate courses to cultivate future interdisciplinary researchers.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Precise primary sequence of natural macromolecules results in complex secondary and tertiary structures and diverse functions. But controlling monomer addition sequence remains a grand challenge in polymer chemistry. This research project aimed to develop a new synthetic strategy based on monomers that selectively undergo a single addition to control the addition sequence of functional monomers along a living polymer chain. This method allows the synthesis of precisely structured polymers with complex macromolecular structures and tailored properties.

Cyclopropenes (CPEs), despite their high ring strain, are underexplored for their polymerization. We reasoned that appropriate substituents may create a kinetic barrier to propagation that is in opposition to CPE's high driving force for ring opening, thus allowing control of the monomer addition reactivity in their ring-opening metathesis polymerization (ROMP). We undertook the first systematic investigation of metathesis reactivity of substituted CPEs and discovered a palette of surprising reactivities, including single-monomer addition, alternating copolymerization, living homopolymerization, no or very slow metathesis reactions, and catalyst deactivation in some cases. Among these reactivities, the most useful and unique is the efficient and exclusive single addition found in two families of CPEs, a rather counterintuitive reactivity for strained cyclic olefins. We have used the single addition CPEs to functionalize the α- and ω-chain ends of ROMP polymers with high efficiency and fidelity, perform alternating copolymerization with controlled molecular weights and incorporated degradable functionalities in the backbones, and precisely place single units of functional moieties and side chains at any desired predetermined locations along a living polymer chain. This project has provided new insights of metathesis chemistry, new patterns of monomer reactivity, and new synthetic strategies to precisely control macromolecular structures and architectures, and thus the properties and behaviors of polymers. We have also revealed the mechanism of single monomer addition for how upon CPE addition certain substituents intramolecularly coordinate to the catalyst and prevent the addition of a second CPE. The general mechanism of action can be applied for designing other monomer families to achieve the unusual single monomer addition and sequence control in polymerization.

In the duration of this project, the importance and excitement of research and polymeric materials have been conveyed to broader communities in several ways. 5 underrepresented high school students have completed 8-week summer internship in the PI?s lab (some are through the ACS SEED program) and became Science ambassadors back at their home schools in the bay area. They presented their research projects and experience at Stanford to the peers at their schools, which are under-resourced and minority serving, to inspire a larger population of students to pursue STEM study. Annual outreach events have been held either at local high schools (such as Scientists Eat and Greet) or on Stanford campus (such as SPLASH and serving as judges in science fairs) to demonstrate how (macro)molecular structures impart diverse properties of materials and talk about career paths for STEM majors as well as college applications. The Xia group has also annually participated in large bay area science outreach events that attract thousands of K-12 students and adult visitors annually, including the Bay Area Science Fair and/or educational night at the California Academy of Sciences, to demonstrate the concepts of polymers and different types of soft materials in our daily lives and convey the message of fostering/accelerating the next generation of technology through basic research. Amid the COVID pandemic, when in-person interns and visits were not possible, we moved outreach activity online using Zoom to talk about different topics that are appealing to the public and pre-college students, such as the polymers used in N95 and other masks, followed by live chemistry demos and a tour of labs.

For curriculum development, the PI has redesigned the undergraduate organic chemistry lab to introduce polymer synthesis and emphasize on problem analysis and solving. The PI has also redesigned the graduate level physical organic chemistry course to interface organic chemistry with materials science with an emphasis on molecular structure - property relationships and problem-based active learning.


Last Modified: 11/04/2021
Modified by: Yan Xia

Image
  • Highilght of diverse metathesis reactivity of cyclopropenes and their use for the synthesis of controlled and sequence-regulated polymers
    Yan Xia
    Copyrighted
